His clothes are quite wet. He might have even fallen. He looks disgustedly at the piano, then lurches toward it. There is no doubt now as the state of his drunkenness. At the piano he viciously sweeps all the note paper off the music stand. This seems to give him some satisfaction, but he loses his balance, twists sideways, and fall into a nearby chair. He remains there, bleary-eyed and a little sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP What he has observed seems to give Jeff an idea. He moves his wheelchair backward and to the left alongside the side board. Awkwardly, with his left hand, he reaches up for a bottle of whiskey. He cradles the bottle in his lap, and reaches for a tumbler. He then wheels back to the window, and pours himself a good, long drink. He lifts up the glass, starts to drink, but something happening beyond his window startles him and he stops in the middle of his drink, his eyes a little wider then usual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman is again leaving his apartment with his aluminum suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes travel down to the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT A brief moment or two. Then the salesman, carrying his aluminum case, crosses the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff's face is expressionless. He just stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff's head is nodding and dozing again. The side light from the song-writer's apartment is no longer on his face. Jeff's eyes open, then his head comes up quickly, trying to clear the sleep from his mind, as he remembers the object of his vigilance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The salesman's apartment shows the shades drawn and a dim light burning behind them. The CAMERA PANS to the empty corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes turn sharply in the direction of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The street is deserted. At the right hand side of the screen a light goes on. THE CAMERA PANS OVER and we see that Miss Torso has returned from her date. She is wearing a three- quarter length coat over her evening dress. She is inside, with the door two-thirds closed, but she leans out to kiss someone goodnight. Then it takes some coaxing to get the door completely closed. She turns the key in the lock. She listens a moment then comes to the center of the room. She takes her coat off and drapes it over chair. She removes the screen in front of the ice box, then opens the ice box. She searches it for something to eat; finds a big piece of pumpkin pie. She closes the ice box. She starts to eat the pie as she moves in the direction of the bathroom. Stopping a moment, she puts the piece of pie on a table, and proceeds to take off her dress. Undoing the zippers, she slides it over her head as she passes into the bathroom. The dress is thrown on a nearby chair, and the bare arm picks up a piece of pie. She is now in the bathroom. We see her slip down the brassiere straps, but the window does not permit us to see any lower. As she munches on the pie, she pulls out a few pins holding up her hair, which she proceeds to brush rhythmically. She turns and moves down her bare back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes suddenly switch to the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI LONG SHOT We catch a quick glimpse of the salesman, just passing the alleyway, suitcase in hand. The CAMERA PANS across the ballet dancer's apartment, over to the salesman's apartment. It waits, until he appears in the corridor. He enters his apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff sits in his wheelchair, looking quietly out at the neighborhood, sleep beginning to take hold on him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LONG SHOT THE CAMERA PANS slightly over the whole of the neighborhood. The lights in Miss Torso's apartment snap out. Only one light remains. It burns behind the drawn shades of the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAWN - CLOSEUP A big head of Jeff. He is still in his wheelchair, sound asleep. The CAMERA PANS off his face, out through the window. The rain has stopped, and the general light of dawn is coming up. The CAMERA COMES TO REST on the salesman's apartment and corridor, which is still dimly lit by the electric lights. We see the salesman emerge into the corridor, pause a moment to allow a woman to proceed him. Her back is to the CAMERA and we do not see her face. They move away, down the corridor. The CAMERA PANS BACK into Jeff's sleeping face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - LONG SHOT It is now mid-morning. The sun is shining. Miss Torso is practicing her dance to the sound of ballet music. We can hear the song-writer at work, but the thing that attracts our attention mostly, is some action that emanates from the fire escape where the couple sleep at night. On a long rope, the woman is lowering an open wicker basket in which sits a small dog. When is reaches the yard below, the CAMERA PANNING DOWN, the dog steps out and runs off to explore the yard. The woman pulls up the basket, and leaves it on the fire escape. The CAMERA PULL BACK into Jeff's apartment where Stella is busy massaging Jeff's back at he lies face down on the divan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella hits a sore muscle in Jeff's back. He jumps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think the rain would have cooled things off. All it did was make the heat wet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a stiff one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT A low camera has Jeff's head on the foreground, with Stella just behind him, at work on his back. She attacks the sore muscle vigorously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops massaging, reaches for the oil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella hits his back with a palmful of cold oil. It takes his breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She helps him to a sitting position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff turns his head away for a moment. She helps him into the chair. Hands him his shirt, which he proceeds to put on. The back of his chair is to the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The insurance Company would be a lot happier if you slept in your bed, not the wheelchair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Between clenched teeth) How did you know!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eyes bloodshot. Must have been staring out the window for hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Massaging harder) What'll you do if one of them catches you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends one which one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now Miss Torso, for example --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your mind off her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's real eat, drink and be merry girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And she'll end up fat, alcoholic and miserable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking of misery, Miss Lonely Hearts drank herself to sleep again. Alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Poor girl. Someday she'll find her happiness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And some man will lose his.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't there anyone in the neighborhood who might cast an eye in her direction?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the salesman could be available soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Interested in the scandal) He and his wife splitting up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hard to figure. He went out several time last night, in the rain carrying his sample case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (So?) Isn't he a salesman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now what could he sell at three in the morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Shrugs) Flashlights. Luminous dials for watches. House numbers that light up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was taking something out of the apartment. I'm certain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His personal effects. He's probably running away -- the coward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes it's worse to stay than it is to run.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looks at him) But it takes a particularly low type of man to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Putting oil and power away) What about this morning? Any developments?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. The shades are still drawn in their apartment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops) In this heat? (Turns, looks over his shoulder) They're up now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP He quickly turns his wheelchair around to the window until he is in profile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman, having just raised the shades in the living room, is now looking out the window. It is not a casual look, but a long, careful, searching appraisal of all the apartment house windows in his neighborhood, starting from his left to his right. His eyes move closer toward Jeff's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff in his chair, facing the window, Stella beside him. Jeff nearly knocks the startled Stella off her feet with his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He propels his chair backward quickly, and Stella moves to the side with surprising agility. They are both in shadow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff keeps his eyes trained on the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella relaxes, gives Jeff a disgusted look, and starts to move out of the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves back into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get back! Out of sight! Quick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (A startled whisper) What is it? What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly) The salesman's looking out his window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Federal offense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sharply) Get back there! He'll see you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not shy. I've been looked at before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Still peering toward window) It's not an ordinary look. It's the kind of look a man gives when he's afraid somebody might be watching him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman completes his searching glance at the neighborhood. Then something directly below his window catches his attention. He looks sharply downward, his body visibly tensing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff, with a restraining hand to Stella, begins to edge his chair cautiously forward so that he can see what the salesman is looking at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT THE CAMERA MOVES FORWARD, and as it reaches the edge of the window, PANS DOWN and shows us what the salesman is looking at. The little dog that was lowered in the basket is sniffing at the salesman's personal flower bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes move up quickly to look at the salesman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman leans forward and grips the window sill as he watches the dog. The CAMERA PANS DOWN and we now see that the old lady with the hearing aid is leaning over the fence admonishing the dog. We can faintly hear her voice saying something to the effect that he'll get into trouble. The dog turns to glance at her and apparently taking heed, moves away. The old lady is wearing a faded house-robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff is amused at the dog incident. Behind him, Stella moves to the center of the room, saying:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She begins putting her equipment back into her black bag. Jeff's eyes lift to the salesman's apartment, and the amusement drains from his face. He leans forward a little, tensely.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Mr. Jefferies. I'll see you tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Grunts) Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman has his aluminum case on the table near the center of the room. He is carefully wiping out the interior with dust cloth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff watching intently. Stella putting the last of her things into her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff continues to what the salesman, his face showing a great concentration of thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella picks up her bag, stares at Jeff's back a moment, then starts for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff swings half-way around in his chair just as Stella reaches the top of the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns around. Jeff points to a coat-stand near the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts down her bag, reaches for the binoculars, takes them out the case. She comes down the stairs, brings them to him. He immediately swings to the window, and lifts them to his eyes. Stella sniffs, then goes to the door, as she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Stella goes out the door, the CAMERA MOVES IN until Jeff's head, and the binoculars, are filling the screen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And don't sleep in the chair again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. Uh-huh. Great conversationalist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Goes on quickly) Will you take those binoculars out of the case and bring them to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trouble. I cam smell it. I'll be glad when they crack that cast, and I get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman has completed his cleaning of the case. He is in the act of placing it on the floor. He turns and again glances out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff quickly lowers the binoculars and edges back a few inches. He watches a moment, then cautiously lifts the binoculars again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (DAY) The man is now moving out of the living room, and the binoculars PAN him though to the small kitchen which is seen through a side window. The man starts to busy himself in this kitchen with his back to us, but the image is very unsatisfactory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the binoculars and there is an expression of exasperation on his face. He throws the binoculars down, and then looks about him. He backs his chair up quickly toward the main cabinet on his left. He leans down, opens a cupboard door and takes out a long-focus lens. Then from a shelf above he takes a small Exacta camera. He quickly takes off the existing lens and puts on the telephoto lens in its place. He wheels himself back to the window and raises the camera to his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSE SHOT Through the view-finder of the camera, we are now brought into close proximity with the salesman in his little kitchen. His back is still to us. He half-turns and takes a used newspaper. He spreads it open, along the drainboard. From the sink he takes out a large butcher's knife, and a long, narrow saw. They disappear from sight as he lays them on the newspaper and proceeds to wrap them up. Having completed his job, he emerges from the kitchen carrying the newspaper- wrapped parcel. For a moment he is lost behind the wall that separates the kitchen recess from the living room. He does not reappear for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the camera for a moment, and watches tensely. Suddenly he puts it up to his eye again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSE SHOT Half of a man's body is now seen in the living room. Then the salesman turns and moves to the center of the room. He is not carrying anything. He sits down on a couch, with a display of fatigue. He yawns and stretches out of sight at full length on the couch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the camera. He watches the living room for a moment. Then his eye travels briefly back to the kitchen; then return to the living room. His brow knits a little as we:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP The thermometer outside of Jeff's window, registering 83 degrees. The CAMERA PANS OFF to the left until it comes to rest on the song-writer's studio. He is dressed only in bathing trunks, and is vigorously cleaning his rug with a carpet sweeper. In the middle of his sweeping, he stops, hurries a step or two to the piano. He plays a couple of notes with one hand, while he stands. Listens, plays them again. Decides they are no good, and returns to his carpet sweeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S FARTHER LEFT to the salesman's apartment. There are no lights burning behind the drawn shade of the bedroom, but the living room and the kitchen are lighted. There is no sign of the salesman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the left, to include the couple who sleep on the fire escape in the hot weather. We now get an opportunity to examine these people more closely. The man is balding, and middle-aged. He is wearing striped pajamas. He is in the act of laying out the mattress. His wife is slightly younger, peroxided, faded show girl type. Also wearing pajamas, with a fluffy handkerchief in the left pocket, the wife is leaning over the railing holding onto the rope which leads to the dog's basket now on the floor of the courtyard. Having been a one-time siffleuse, her call to the dog is clarion and melodic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The little dog emerges reluctantly from the shadows, and steps into the basket. It begins to move upward, and THE CAMERA FOLLOWS it. When the basket reaches the fire escape, THE CAMERA PANS ON to the apartment of Miss Torso. She is in the bathroom brushing her long hair, while her thoughts seem to be far away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the apartment below, occupied by the elderly lady with the hearing aid. For the first time we see something of her activities inside the apartment. She wears a short smock, although her legs are still bare. She is hard at work on a piece of abstract sculpture. It takes the form of a piece of mahogany through which a simple hole has been carved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: much farther to the left, and eventually comes to rest on the newly-weds' apartment with the shade still drawn. It MOVES ON and at last passes though Jeff's window, and comes to rest on the two bid heads of Jeff and Lisa. Her lips are brushing lightly against his cheek as she speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff moves his eyes slightly to something outside the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How far does a girl have to go -- before you notice her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If she's pretty enough, she doesn't have to go anywhere. She just has to "be".
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The salesman's apartment, just as we saw it a moment ago. The shades drawn and lights out in the bedroom, the shade up and lights on in the living room and kitchen. Still no one in sight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, "ain't I?" -- Pay attention to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - TWO SHOT We are now able to see that Jeff's apartment is in darkness, only faintly lit from the distant light of the neighbors' window. By her position, Lisa is seated on Jeff's sound knee, her arms around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts kissing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gives up trying to interest him in romance, and moves back from the embrace. THE CAMERA PULL BACK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa stands, straightens out her dress, stretches a little then she turns to the divan, apparently not too interested in his observation about the salesman's life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff is thoughtful for a moment, then he relaxes and smiles a little. He turns to the window to look out again. Lisa exits the picture.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not exactly on the other side of the room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mind is. And when I want a man, I want all of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you ever have any problems?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Murmurs, kissing him) I have one now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So do I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Kissing) Tell me about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Slight pause) Why would a man leave his apartment three times, on a rainy night, with a suitcase? And come back three times?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He likes the way his wife welcomes him home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that salesman's wife. And why didn't he go to work today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homework. It's more interesting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's interesting about a butcher's knife and a small saw wrapped up in a newspaper?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, thank heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking again) Why hasn't he gone into his wife's bedroom all day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't dare answer that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (After pause) Lisa -- there's something terribly wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm afraid it's with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looks at Lisa) What do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Without returning his look) Something too frightful to utter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa stretches herself out on the divan. Her head rest on the cushion at the far end, and she instinctively falls into an attractive pose. However, her expression is disturbed as she watches Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP He stares intently out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He went out a few minutes ago -- in his undershirt -- and he hasn't come back yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa weighs this information, trying to make some sense out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff turns his eyes from the salesman's apartment, and looks down reflectively. He looks up again, and then his eyes catches sight of something. He leans forward slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Torso is lying, face down, on her divan bed. The only light in the apartment is from a reading lamp. She is reading a book held in one hand, while eating a sandwich in another. Her back is bare, and all she wears is a pair of brief dark blue shorts. At one point, she lifts her torso up slightly to brush crumbs out from beneath her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP He looks away from Miss Torso, thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know -- that would be terrible job to tackle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Lisa leans forward and looks out the window to see what Jeff is referring to. She turns back to him with a blank stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff turns and looks at her, quite unaware of her surprise at his comment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How would you begin to cut up a human body?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa sits bolt upright on the divan. She reaches back quickly and pulls on the overhead light. At that moment the songwriter returns to his composing. We can see him over Lisa's shoulder. He is beginning his song again, and it has taken on new fullness and melody. Although it is not complete, it is farther along then before, and he plays his theme a number of different ways, trying to move it note by note to its completion. Lisa just stares at Jeff for a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- I'll be honest with you -- you're beginning to scare me a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff is staring out of the window again. Over this we hear Lisa's voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff puts out a restraining hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly insistent) Jeff -- did you hear what I said? You're beginning to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Interrupting) Be quiet! Shhh! (Pause) He's coming back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT At last the salesman is seen coming along the corridor. He does not wear shirt, but only an undershirt. Slung over one shoulder, with his arm through is, is a large coil of sturdy rope. He goes through the living room into the bedroom. He does not put on the bedroom lights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff reaches quickly for his binoculars, and trains them on the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT As seen though the binoculars, the salesman comes out of the bedroom, to the kitchen, where he gets a carving knife. He turns around and goes back to the bedroom. The lights go on behind the draw shades, after a short moment. The dim shadow of the salesman is seen moving around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa, still stretched out on the divan looking at Jeff, suddenly sits upright and then getting up from the divan, mover over to Jeff, THE CAMERA GOING WITH her. In a sudden surprise move, she swings his chair completely around so that his back is to the window. He drops the binoculars into his lap in surprise. THE CAMERA MOVES IN as Lisa leans over Jeff, gripping both sides of his chair
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff tries to turn around, but she won't let the chair move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns the wheelchair slightly to her left so that he can see the newlyweds' apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sharply) Jeff -- if you could only see yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Lisa -- LISA (Abruptly) Sitting around, looking out a window to kill time, is one thing -- but doing it the way you are -- (She gestures)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: with, with binoculars, and with wild opinions about every little movement you see -- is, is diseased!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think I consider this recreation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what you consider it -- but if you don't stop it, I'm getting out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd better before you catch the disease!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Insistent) What is it you're looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to find out what's wrong with the salesman's wife. Does that make me sound like a madman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you think something's wrong with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A lot of things. She's an invalid who needs constant care -- and yet the husband nor anyone else has been in there all day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe she died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the doctor -- the undertakers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She could be under sedatives, sleeping. (Looks up) He's in the room now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa, please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing to see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is -- I've seen things through that window! Bickering, family fights, mysterious trips at night, knives, saws, rope -- and since last evening, not a sight or sound of his wife! Now you tell me where she is and what she's doing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he's leaving his wife. I don't know, and I don't care. Lots of people have saws, knives and ropes around their houses. Lots of men don't speak to their wives all day. Lots of wives nag, and men hate them, and trouble starts -- but very, very, very few of them end up in murder -- if that's what you're thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's pretty hard to stay away from that word isn't is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could see all the things he did, couldn't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you getting at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could see that he did because he had the shades in his apartment up, and walked along the corridor, and the streets and the backyard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff, do you think a murderer would let you see all that? That he shouldn't keep his shades down and hide behind them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where he's being clever. Acting nonchalant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's where you're not being clever. He wouldn't parade his crime in front of the open shades.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pointing) For all you know -- there's something a lot more sinister going on behind those shades.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The drawn shades of the newlyweds' apartment. A dim light burning behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff looks, turns back to her, trying to suppress a chuckle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa half looks up and out the window. She opens her mouth to answer, but a new look overtakes her face. It is concern, surprise, and a little shock. Jeff sees the change, is sobered, and quickly turns the chair around. He looks out the window, using his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No comment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you see how silly you're being?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Lisa -- probably you're right. He's probably in the bedroom now, entertaining his wife with the indian rope trick. I'll admit to criminal insanity. Now when do I start the cure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The shades in the bedroom are now up. Both beds are empty, and stripped of their linen, the mattresses thrown up over the end of the beds. The salesman, sweating heavily, stands over a large, square trunk in the center of the room. It is stoutly bound by the heavy rope we previously saw him bring into the apartment. He wipes one forearm across his brow, and then heads for the kitchen. In the kitchen, he produces a bottle, pours himself two or three straight drinks, then leans with a display of exhaustion against the kitchen sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff lowers the glasses. His look is sober. Lisa stands behind him, one hand on the back of the wheelchair. She, too, is serious. THE CAMERA MOVES IN until Lisa's head fills the screen. She says, slowly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is still staring out the window, as the scene
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's start from the beginning again, Jeff. Tell me everything you saw -- and what you think it means.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff is seated in the dark, his face lit by the faint glow from the distant street. He is looking out of the window tensely, as THE CAMERA MOVES IN, until he is in big profile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LONG SHOT From Jeff's viewpoint, all the windows are dark. The couple are sleeping on the fire escape. The salesman's apartment is dark as well. Suddenly a match flares, and we see the salesman light a cigar. The flame of the match illuminates his face for a moment. When is dies out, we see just the glow of the cigar burning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP The CAMERA is now facing Jeff. We see that his left hand rests on the telephone receiver which is close to him. The phone starts to RING, but makes only the slightest sound, as he instantly picks it up. As he talks, in a low voice, he keeps his eyes on the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP We get an impression of Sixth Avenue behind Lisa at the phone. Lisa also talks in a low, quiet voice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The name on the second floor rear mailbox reads Mr. And Mrs. Lars, that's L-A-R-S, Lars Thorwald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Filter) What's the apartment house number?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: West Ninth Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff, still looks toward the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Lisa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Lisa smilingly says:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, chief. What's my next assignment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To get on home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- but what's he doing now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff is still looking toward the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts the receiver down, and resumes his vigil.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just sitting in the living room. In the dark. And he hasn't gone near the bedroom. Now get some sleep. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LONG SHOT All we can see is the glow of the salesman's cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff is seated by the window in his wheelchair. He is talking on the telephone while his eyes are still on the neighborhood. There is a touch of urgency in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK slightly as Stella emerges from the kitchen. She is carrying a tray with breakfast on it. Eggs, bacon, toast and coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella squeezes past the right side of Jeff, and places the food tray on a windowseat in front of him. She peers out cautiously toward Thorwald's apartment for a moment. Then she squeezes back, moving to the sideboard against which leans a small table on an adjustable stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella returns with the table, and sets it up so that it is across Jeff's lap. She gets the tray of food pausing to look toward Thorwald's apartment. Then she places the breakfast on the tray table in front of Jeff. He has moved back a little to avoid getting the phone cable tangled in the food and dishes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Doyle -- it's just one of those things I can't tell you on the phone. You have to be here, and see the whole set-up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's probably nothing important -- just a little neighborhood murder, that's all. As a matter of fact, I did say "murder".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My only thought was to throw a little business your way. A good detective, I reasoned, would jump at the chance to detect.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I usually took my best pictures on my day off. (nods) Okay, Doyle -- soon as you can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP He hangs up. Stella takes the phone and puts it down for him. He looks at the breakfast, reaches for a knife and fork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins eating, appreciatively. She moves behind his chair, pausing to look toward Thorwald's apartment again. Jeff is just lifting a piece of bacon to his lips when Stella speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hand carrying the bacon to Jeff's mouth hesitates for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hand holding the bacon moves back to the plate. Jeff just stares ahead. Stella turns and walks into the kitchen. Jeff pushes the food away, and picks up the coffee cup instead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stella, I -- I can't tell you what a welcome sight this is. No wonder your husband's still in love with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pauses in cutting food) Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You called the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Well, yes and no. It wasn't an official call. He's just a friend. (Almost to himself) An old, ornery friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Half to herself) Now just where do you suppose he cut her up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Answering herself) Oh -- of course! In the bathtub. That's the only place he could wash away the blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes, over the coffee cup, are staring intently at the backyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. The shades up. No one moving. The rope-tied trunk still sits in the bedroom. To the left we see the basket lowering with the dog in it. We HEAR the woman WHISTLING an aria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP His eyes stray in an upward direction as he puts down the coffee cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The CAMERA PANS UP past the woman lowering the dog, up to the roof where one of the sunbathers can be seen sitting up, rubbing her body with sun tan oil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff's eyes moves down again. Abstractedly his hand strays toward the piece of bacon. He picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. We are now aware that the salesman is now in his living room, lying out of sight on the sofa, because the smoke from a newly lighted cigar is starting to ascend toward the ceiling of his room. Stella's voice is heard calling out from the kitchen:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He'd better get that trunk out of there before is starts to leak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Again the bacon stops before is reaches Jeff's mouth. He puts it down on the plate again, as his eyes move slightly toward the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Torso, in ballet outfit, is hanging up a small wash on a clothes line. It consists mostly of lingerie. She is doing her inevitable leg practice at the same time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S OVER SUDDENLY TO Thorwald's apartment, and except for the smoke rising from the unseen sofa, there is no activity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff seems to be getting a bit listless, or bored, by constantly watching Thorwald's apartment. His eyes sort of stray around the neighborhood, and end up looking toward:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT The newlywed's apartment. Shade down, business as usual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff smiles affectionately, and starts to turn his eyes away; but something startles him, and he looks quickly back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT The shade suddenly going up in the newlywed's apartment. The young husband leans his hands on the windowsill, and looks out. He is wearing only his pajama bottoms, because of the heat, and we see that he is a well-muscled, attractive young man. He looks around with some satisfaction. He turns at the sound of a woman's voice behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his head, is thoughtful for a brief moment, then he pulls down the shade.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: H-a-a-r-r-e-e...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP His smile almost becomes a private chuckle. Stella's abrupt voice breaks in urgently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff's head snaps toward the center of his window. Stella has appeared behind his wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look! Look -- Mr. Jefferies!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Two men wearing tan coveralls are standing outside Thorwald's door. One of them carries a clipboard. Suddenly Thorwald is seen sitting up on the living room sofa. His hair is disheveled and he is unshaved. He stands up, and moves toward the door. He opens it, and after a short exchange of dialogue, he admits the two men, leaving the door open behind them. He leads the two man across the living room to the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Stella and Jeff watching intently. He is feeling down alongside his wheelchair for his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - BINOCULAR SHOT A close view shows the two man carrying the trunk across the living room toward the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the binoculars quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella moves toward the door quickly. Jeff turns quickly over his shoulder to watch her. She is already going up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Stella goes out the door, she calls back:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear nothing from Stella, but the sound of her heavy tread down the hallway stairs. Jeff returns to Thorwald. He eases himself back into the shadows a bit and then raises his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Agitated) I thought Doyle would get here before the trunk went -- or I'd have called the police. (To Stella) Now we're going to lose it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stella, don't do anything reckless!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just going to get the name of their truck!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Up) I'll watch the alleyway -- in case it goes that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - BINOCULAR SHOT Jeff concentrates his attention on the alley-way that leads to the street. Just normal traffic. The binoculars swing to Thorwald apartment. The salesman is now at the telephone. He has picked up the receiver, and proceeds to dial 221.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP The binoculars still up to Jeff's face. Under them his mouth moves, as if he's talking to himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Long Distance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - BINOCULAR SHOT The salesman speaks some words to the operator. Placing the call. As he does this, he reaches with his other hand for a nearly bottle, and working the cork out with one hand, he pours a stiff drink into a tumbler. He drinks it as soon as he finishes talking with the operator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the binoculars a little, and takes a normal eye sight on the alleyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - LONG SHOT Pulling across to the far side of the street we see the hood and cab of a freight truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff quickly puts the glasses up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - BINOCULAR SHOT By the time the binoculars are up, another truck has crossed from the left. In momentarily blocks out the side of our freight truck. By the time the two trucks part, we can only see the back half of the freight truck before it pulls out of sight. Jeff is only able to read the words "FREIGHT LINES". The binoculars are held for a moment until we see a puffing and blowing Stella arrive at the opening of the alleyway. She looks toward the front of Thorwald's apartment house. And by her attitude we can see that there is no truck outside. She looks about her for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the binoculars, discouraged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - LONG SHOT The figure of Stella is seen, looking up toward Jeff's apartment, and arms outspread in a helpless gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT SHOOTING TOWARDS the big window, with the neighborhood beyond, Jeff is as usual seated in his wheelchair on the left of the window, but now turned toward a newcomer. The second man is standing near the divan looking out the window with the binoculars. This newcomer is POLICE DETECTIVE LIEUTENANT THOMAS J. DOYLE, the man Jeff phoned earlier in the day. He is an intelligent-appearing, well-dressed modern detective. He has a sense of humor. He lowers the glasses, and turns to Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle paces a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle saunters toward steps, picking up his hat on the way. Stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes up the steps to the door, putting on his hat. He pauses his hand on the door knob.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't see the killing, or the body? How do you know there was a murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because everything that man's done has been suspicious. Trips at night in the rain, saws, knives, trunks with rope, and a wife that isn't there any more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll admit it all has a mysterious sound -- but is could mean a number of different things. Murder is the least likely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, Doyle -- tell me he's an unemployed magician -- amusing the neighborhood with sleight-of-hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too stupid and obvious a way to murder -- in full view of fifty windows -- and then sit over there -- (He points)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: smoking a cigar -- waiting for the police to pick him up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, officer -- do your duty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got a lot to lean about homicide, Jeff. Morons have committed murder so shrewdly that it took a hundred trained police minds to catch them. That salesman wouldn't just knock off his wife after dinner, toss her in a trunk and put her in storage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bet it's been done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Almost everything's been done -- under panic. But this is a thousand to one shot. That man's still sitting around his apartment; he isn't panicked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (A pause) You think I made all this up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you saw something -- that probably has a very simple explanation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For instance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Shrugs) His wife took a trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She -- was -- an -- invalid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You told me. (Looks at watch) I've got to run, Jeff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- you don't believe me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: uh -- won't report it to the Department. Let me poke into a little on my own. No point in you getting any ridiculous publicity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Coldly) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We know the wife is gone. I'll see if I can find out where.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have any headaches lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff answers, showing only the slightest irritation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not 'til you showed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle, still at the door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to go out the door, and closes it behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. Well, it'll wear off in time -- along with the hallucinations. See you around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT From Doyle's viewpoint. Jeff lifts his hand in a feeble parting gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Before the door has completely closed, Doyle opens it again, and looks in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: By the way  what happened to your leg?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP JEFF I was jaywalking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (With nonchalance) The Indianapolis Speedway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP The door starts to close again, as if Doyle considered Jeff's answer quite reasonable. Then the door pops open and Doyle's head comes in, a surprised expression across his face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: During the race?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff answers with a straight face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't see Doyle again, but only HEAR the sharp slam of the DOOR off. Jeff chuckles. Then he turns back to the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yup. It sure stopped traffic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff's attention is drawn to something in the yard below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT The little dog is busily scratching away at Thorwald's pet flower bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff smiles mischievously. Suddenly his face changes as he sees:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald coming out of his basement door, carrying a watering can. He fills it from a nearby faucet. He does not notice the little dog's destructive activities. When the watering can is filled, he straightens up, turns toward the flower bed. He stops for the briefest moment, when he sees the dog. He walks to the dog, gently lifts him out of the garden, and giving him a friendly little pat, sends him off. He proceeds to patiently brush back the disturbed earth, and then begins his watering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff is frankly puzzled by the salesman's friendly attitude toward the dog. He looks off in another direction, as he catches of:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - LONG SHOT Doyle, who has appeared, at the street opening. The detective is surveying the front of the apartment building where Thorwald lives. A paper seller behind him offers to sell him a paper. Doyle isn't interested. As Doyle saunters forward toward the salesman house, the scene:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - MEDIUM SHOT Doyle is nonchalantly leaning up against the side board, with a highball in one hand. Jeff has turned his chair around from the window to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff looks thoughtful a moment, and then says, with a touch of discouragement:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts down his drink, and strolls toward the window, looking out. THE CAMERA MOVES IN slightly to tighten the shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle becomes interested in watching something out the window. Unconsciously he smooths out his coat and tie. He even smiles somewhat secretly to himself at what he sees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He has a six months lease, and has used up a little over five and a half months of it. (Takes a sip of drink) Quiet. Drinks, but not to drunkenness. Pays his bill promptly, with money earned as a consume jewelry salesman -- wholesale. Keeps to himself, and none of the neighbors got close to him, or his wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think they missed their chance with her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Studies drink) She never left the apartment -- JEFF (Interrupting) Then where is she -- in the ice box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Continues)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: until yesterday morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Alert) What time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Six ayem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that's about the time I fell asleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad. The Thorwalds were just leaving the apartment house at that time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Feel a little foolish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Torso, in ballet costume, practicing her dance on the outside balcony. She is exciting and desirable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - TIGHT TWO SHOT Jeff notices Doyle's interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Startled at being observed, Doyle moves quickly away from the window, affecting nonchalance. THE CAMERA MOVES BACK as Doyle returns to his drink. Jeff smiles at catching Doyle enjoying Miss Torso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses off the rest of the drink, and his movement is almost a comment. Jeff's face grows serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle quickly collects his thoughts, and gets back to the case at hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't help smiling, and neither can Doyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to the sideboard, picks up a felt hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls a slip of paper out of his pocket. Jeff watches him intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at Jeff with some smugness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts on his hat, and goes toward the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's your wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- oh, she's fine. (Not too convincing) Just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who said they left then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who left -- where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Thorwalds -- at six in the morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The building superintendent, and two tenants. Flat statements -- no hesitation. And they all jibed to the letter. The Thorwalds were leaving for the railroad station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now how could anybody guess that? They had, perhaps, signs on their luggage, "Grand Central Or Bust!"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sighs) The superintendent met Thorwald coming back. He said Thorwald told him he had just put his wife on the train for the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A very convenient guy -- this superintendent. Have you checked his bank deposits lately?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sharply) Well -- what good is his information?!! It's a second-hand version of an unsupported statement by the murderer himself -- Thorwald! Anybody actually see the wife get on the train?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hate to remind you -- but this all started because you said she was murdered. Now did anyone, including you, actually see her murdered?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doyle -- are you interested in solving a case, or making me look foolish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If possible -- both.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well then do a good job of it! Get over there, and search Thorwald's apartment! It must be knee-deep in evidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean when he goes out for a paper, or a drink, or something. What he doesn't know won't hurt him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do it even if he's gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (With sarcasm) What's the matter? Does he have a courtesy card from the police department?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now don't get me mad! Even a detective can't walk in anybody's apartment and search it. If I were ever caught in there, I'd lose my badge inside of ten minutes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just make sure you're not caught. If you find something, you've got a murderer and nobody will care about a couple of house rules. If you find nothing -- he's clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the risk of sounding stuffy, Jeff -- I'll remind you of the Constitution, and the phrase "search warrant" issued by a judge who knows the Bill of Rights verbatim. He must ask for evidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give him evidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can hear myself starting out. "Your Honor -- I have a friend who's an amateur sleuth, an one night, after a heavy supper --" (He shakes his head "no") He'd throw the New York State Penal Code right in my face. -- And it's six volumes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By morning there might not be anything left to find in his apartment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking out window) A detective's nightmare.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you need before you can search -- bloody footsteps leading up to the door?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking out window) One thing I don't need is heckling! You called and asked me for help -- and now you're acting like a taxpayer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Turns and look at Jeff) How did we ever stand each other in that same plane for three years?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, every day for three years I asked myself that same question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever get an answer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah -- frequently -- it ran something like this: "Your request for transfer turned down --"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry I had to turn it down. (He checks his watch) I'm going over to the railroad station and check Thorwald's story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget the story -- find the trunk. Mrs. Thorwald's in it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- I almost forgot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking at Jeff) There was a postcard in Thorwald's mailbox. (Refers to paper) Mailed yesterday afternoon, three- thirty P.M. from Merritsville -- (Looks up, speaks pleasantly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's eighty miles north of here. (Back to paper) The message read "Arrived O.K. Already feeling better. Love, Anna."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Slowly) Is -- is Anna -- who I think it is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Nods "yes") Mrs. Thorwald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Maliciously) Anything you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - CLOSEUP Jeff is sober.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. A good detective.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP The sun has just set. THE CAMERA is concentrating on the long-focus lens camera which fills the screen. Just beyond, there is a plate on which a solitary sandwich. Jeff's hand comes in, picks it up. We PAN US with the sandwich until Jeff's head fills the screen. (Except for a small light in the kitchen, Jeff's apartment is in darkness.) As he munches, he keeps his attention on the neighborhood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment is darkness. THE CAMERA PANS slightly to the left, as we see the dog being lowered in its basket. We follow the basket down to the yard which brings Miss Lonely Heart's apartment into view. She is wearing a Kelly Green suit, and is seated at her dressing table. She seems to be putting on the final touches of her make-up, prior to going out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP Jeff looks down, he smiles to himself. He turns, and we see him raise the long-focus camera to his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CAMERA SHOT The long-focus lens brings Miss Lonely Hearts into an enlarged picture which reveals details we have not previously noticed. A pair of ill-fitting, horn-rimmed reading glasses rest half way down her nose, and she has to tilt her head back slightly as she applies lip-stick, with their aid. Satisfied, she takes off the glasses, and examines her face as a whole, through squinting eyes. She has faded good looks, has fairly nice clothes, but is badly in need of advice on hair dressing. Her hair-do makes her seem middle-aged. She reaches for a tall glass of liquor next to her, and takes a long drink. Putting the glass down, she squints to see if she has disturbed the lipstick. Unable to see clearly, she puts on the glasses again, looks, and touches up her lips slightly. She puts her glasses in a handbag, then stands to put out the lights. She walks into the living room, finishing the drink. The long-focus lens moves with her. She goes straight for a bottle of liquor, and pours out a final neat slug, and tosses it off. Then she leaves the apartment, with a show of determination. She turns out the lights behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the long-focus lens, and turns his head to the right as he hears the first notes of the songwriter's melody which we have heard him trying to complete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT The songwriter is at the piano, poking out his melody, slowly, note by note. He is in black tie, and from the looks of the apartment he is preparing for guests. An attractive girl is setting out trays of canapes, glasses, ice and liquor. She pauses as she crosses the room carrying a tray of food. She listens a moment to the songwriter's melody. Her expression shows that it pleases her, and moves her romantically. She comments on it to the songwriter, who starts from the beginning again, playing it more fully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-CLOSEUP A new source of music comes in to interfere with the piano playing. It is orchestral ballet music, in a modern style. Jeff's head turns in this new direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Torso, and a male partner whom we have not seen before, are practicing a pas a deux. He is a tall flowing-haired young man, lithe and graceful beyond normal masculine capacity. They stop, at one point, to listen to a word of comment from a woman who is watching. By her gestures, she is obviously a professional choreographer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S from this to the street beyond. Standing there, on the sidewalk, looking up and down the street is a Kelly Green clad figure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP He quickly raises his long-focus camera to his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CAMERA SHOT We are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjustment by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. She seems to be trying to figure out what to do, or where to go. She nervously looks at a couple of men passers by. Getting no reaction, she crosses the street, and seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe. She orders a drink. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a man who enters the picture from the left side. He is much nearer the lens, because he is on this side of the street. He is, therefore, slightly out of focus. The lens suddenly sharpens. It is Thorwald, carrying a light-weight cardboard box under his arm. THE CAMERA PANS him over to the right until he is lost behind the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-CLOSEUP He lowers the lens, and we see Jeff's eyes travel across the screen, as he imagines Thorwald's progression. Then sharpening his look, he picks up the long-focus lens, and easing himself back cautiously, begins watching Thorwald.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CAMERA SHOT Thorwald comes up the corridor, and stands unlocking his door. As he hesitates, we are able to see the cardboard box he is carrying has the name of a laundry on it. He enters the apartment turns on the living room lights. He proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of suits and top coats are lying on an orderly pile on the bed. He takes the laundry out of the box and puts in on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, he proceeds to take out the contents of the drawers -- pajamas, shirts, sox, etc. He piles these on the beds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the camera quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answered by a woman:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment, Jeff looks desperate. He doesn't know what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. Then, his brows knit a little, as if he's puzzled about something he sees across the neighborhood. He lifts up the long-focus lens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE (Filter) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Doyle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff again. (A note of urgency) Has Tom come in yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE Not yet, Jeff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't even heard from him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE Not a word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE It is something really important, Jeff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid it is, Tess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE I'll have him call the moment I hear from him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell him not to waste time calling. To get over here soon as he can. I think Thorwald's pulling out tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE Who's Thorwald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows. (As an after-thought) Don't worry, Tess. It's a man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DOYLE (She laughs) Goodnight, you idiot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (A slight smile) Goodnight, Mrs Doyle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Early night. In the dresser Thorwald finds an alligator handbag. He holds it up thoughtfully. We have previously seen this handbag hanging from the bedpost when Mrs. Thorwald was in bed. Thorwald takes the bag into the living room, where he picks up the phone and dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thorwald reaches his party. As he talks, thoughtfully, he takes some jewelry from the handbag -- a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. He discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Then, seemingly satisfied, he replaces them in the bag and hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Long distance again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. But a sudden rise in the SOUND coming from the song-writer's apartment, causes him to turn his head toward the studio with exasperation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The first four of the song-writer's guests come through the door, admitted by the song-writer's girl friend. There is a squeal from the woman who great each other, and hearty "helloes" from the men. The song-writer dashes off a LOUD VAMP of greeting on the piano, then gets up to offer drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald, but gives up any attempt at listening. He lift the long-focus lens up to his eyes again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Having completed his call, Thorwald returns to the bedroom carrying the handbag. He goes to a pile of coats lying on the bed. He lifts the top two coats slightly, and slides the handbag under them and out of sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP There is the SOUND of footsteps coming down the corridor to Jeff's apartment. He lowers the camera lens, and turns his attention to his door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The door opens, and Lisa stands silhouetted in the entrance, black-lighted by the corridor lights. It's an attractive picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff's head is turned toward her, his back more toward the neighborhood.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Quick. Take a look. Thorwald's getting ready to pull out for good!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff abruptly turns back to the window, as Lisa dashes into the picture behind him, and looks out. Jeff's expression changes a little, as they see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The lights are out in Thorwald's bedroom, and Thorwald is in the act of pouring himself out a drink in the living room. He comes to the window, glass in hand, and looks down into the garden, nonchalantly. Over this, we HEAR Lisa's voice, questioningly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. JEFF'S APARTMENT - NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT He stops, turns to her quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff turns back to the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't seem to be in any hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Stares out the window, exasperated) He was just laying all his things out on one of the beds! Coats, suits, shirts, sox, even his wife's --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That alligator bag his wife had on the bedpost -- LISA What about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had it hidden in the dresser! Well, at least it was in there. He took it out, went to the phone and called somebody long distance. -- His wife's jewelry was in the handbag. And something about it worried him. He was asking somebody advice over the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone not his wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw him ask her for advise before. (Smiles) But she volunteered plenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald is standing at the window with his drink in his hand. Then he turns, puts his unfinished drink down on a table, and goes to the door. He puts the light out in the living room and goes out the door. He walks briskly down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder where he's going now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose he doesn't come back again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He will. All his things are still piled on the bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa moves toward a nearby lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up the long-focus lens and trains it on the street intersection, as Lisa moves back to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I guess it's safe to put on some lights now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking to left) Not yet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The street intersection. Some traffic, mostly pedestrian. Miss Lonely Hearts still sitting at the cafe table, alone. Drinking. There is no sign of Thorwald.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT He lowers the lens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK as Lisa starts around the apartment turning on the lights. As she light increases, we see that she is wearing another extravagantly beautiful dress. She seems quite animated, moving gracefully, her skirt and hair swinging with her movement. Jeff turns around to face the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he talks, she seems to be thinking something over to herself. He starts pacing, trying to distill her thoughts. We see that she has brought an oversized handbag with her, which lies prominently on the table. Jeff watches her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He must have gone somewhere to the right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All day long I've tried to keep my mind on work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thinking about Thorwald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Nods yes) And you, and you friend Doyle -- (Stops, to Jeff) Did you hear from him again -- since he left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a word. He was going to check on the railroad station, and the trunk. He must be still on it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something on your mind, Lisa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't make sense to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What doesn't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Women aren't that unpredictable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Losing a little patience) Lisa -- I can't guess what you're thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S IN, Lisa stops, faces him. Her eyes sparkle, and her body is tense with concentration.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A woman has a favorite handbag -- it always hangs on her bedpost where she can get at it. Then she takes a trip and leaves it behind. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because she didn't know she was going on a trip -- and where she was going she wouldn't need a handbag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: eases back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes over to Jeff. He reaches up, takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls her into his lap. She puts her arms around him. She is very happy, and kisses Jeff's cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a pause. Then Jeff moves back a little to look her straight in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cuts him off with a kiss. When she pulls back
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa smothers him with another kiss. She lets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smothers him with still another kiss. Then moves back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs, gets up. Goes to the large handbag on the table. Is is a Mark Cross ladies 'attache' case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has opened it, and surprisingly enough, it is a compact outfit of pajamas, slippers, toothbrush, toothpaste, and all the general necessities for a comfortable overnight stay. She comes to Jeff, sits in his lap again, displaying the inside of the case
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The SOUND from the party in the song-writer's apartment becomes more noticeable as his party grows. And at this point he begins playing the song he has been composing for the past few days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up from Jeff's lap, and puts the overnight case on the table. Open. She goes to the window, and looks toward the song-writers' apartment. Jeff turns with her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But only her husband would know that. (Starts to pace again) And the jewelry! Women don't keep all their jewelry in a purse, all tangled, getting scratched and twisted up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do they hide it in their husband's clothes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do not! And they don't leave it behind them. A woman going anywhere but the hospital would always take makeup, perfume and jewelry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Inside stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Basic equipment. You don't leave it behind in your husband's drawer in your favorite handbag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm with you, sweetie, but Detective Thomas J. Doyle has a pat answer for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That Mrs. Thorwald left at six ayem yesterday with her husband?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what the witnesses told him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I have a pat rebuttal for Mr. Doyle -- that couldn't be Mrs. Thorwald -- or I don't know women.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still -- those witnesses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll agree they saw a woman -- but she wasn't Mrs. Thorwald. -- That is, yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to see your friend's face when we tell him. He doesn't sound like much of a detective.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be too hard on him. He's a steady worker. I wish he'd get there, though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Nuzzling Jeff) Don't rush me. We have all night.
dialogue.name: dialogue
