dialogue.raw_text: We have all -- what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Night. I'm going to stay with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll have to clear that through my landlord --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have the whole weekend off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well that's fine, but I only have one bed, and --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say anything else, and I'll stay tomorrow night too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa, I won't be able to give you any --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: pajamas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said I'd have to live out of one suitcase (Picks up case) I'll bet yours isn't this small?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a suitcase?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Starting to open it) A Mark Cross overnight case, anyway. Compact, but ample enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll trade you -- my feminine intuition for a bed for the night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Gives in smiling) I'd be no better than Thorwald, to refuse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's that song again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The party at the song-writer's has grow considerably larger. An assortment of well-dressed people have now crowded into the studio. They are drinking, eating, etc. At the moment, a number of them are crowded around the piano, listening to the composer's newest song -- which isn't quite completed. However, the melody has become more beautiful than ever. During the following scene, we HEAR the melody being played a number of different ways on the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa stands, listening, entranced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits down on the edge of the divan near Jeff. She leans toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to the kitchen, humming with the song-writer's melody which we can HER off. Jeff turns back to the window, looks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where does a man get the inspiration for a song like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From his landlord -- once a month.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's utterly beautiful. (Turns to Jeff) I wish I could be creative.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are. You have a talent for creating difficult situations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Happily) I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Staying the night here, uninvited.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Surprise -- is the most important element of attack. (She smiles) And beside, you're not up on your private eye literature. When they're in trouble, it's always their Girl Friday who gets them out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The same girl who keeps him out of the clutches of seductive show girls, and over-passionate daughters of the rich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he never ends up marrying her. Strange.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Stands up; deadpan) Weird. (She does a complete spin, then, ingenuously) Why don't I slip into something comfortable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean -- like the kitchen? And make us some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Exactly what I had in mind -- along with some brandy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The shade is going up in the newlyweds apartment. The young husband throws up the window an lights a cigarette. He takes a deep and satisfying drag on the cigarette, glancing toward the song-writer's party. Just as he starts to exhale the smoke, we HEAR his young wife's voice off:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chokes on the smoke, sputtering and coughing. When he recovers, he throws the cigarette down to the back-yard with a show of irritation. Then slowly he pulls the shade down. Behind us is SOUND of a door shutting
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: H-a-a-r-r-e-e-!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Over Jeff's shoulder we see Doyle coming down the steps slowly, and seemingly preoccupied. Jeff swings the chair around so that his back is to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without looking at Jeff, Doyle comes into the apartment takes off his hat and places it on the table. He runs a hand over the side of his head and down the back of his neck, which seems to indicate some fatigue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff. Looking expectantly at Doyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle reaches for a cigarette on the table, and puts it to his lips. While searching his pockets for a match, he HEARS Lisa humming. His eyes turn upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over the cabinet which divides the living room from the kitchen, we can see a glimpse of Lisa's shadow on the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff, has followed Doyle's look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle picks up cigarette lighter from table, and lights his cigarette. As he is placing the lighter back on the table, he sees:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From his viewpoint, Lisa's bag containing her lingerie and overnight effects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff. His eyes turn from the lingerie up to Doyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle's look is completely noncommittal. His eyes turn at the sound of the song-writer's party. He moves forward to get a better view, as the CAMERA RETREATS in front of him. He stops to glance out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The party is now full progress. The room is overcrowded. And some people are now sitting on the floor with their backs to the window. Others are outside. A crowd hides the piano player, but music can be head competing with the babble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Doyle turns his head away, and looks straight out. His expression hardens a little, as he sees:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT The window of Thorwald's apartment, completely dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP He also is looking toward Thorwald's apartment. He turns his eyes anxiously back to Doyle. He seems to be trying to penetrate Doyle's mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Doyle turns his head from the window, and looks down at Jeff. He asks, quietly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff's tension eases off a little, by he is eager to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle looks back toward Thorwald's bedroom. We see the dark apartment beyond him. Doyle nods thoughtfully. He turns his head suddenly at the sound of Lisa coming out of the kitchen. She holds two large brandy snifters containing some brandy. They are cupped in her hand, the stem between her fingers. She is rotating them gently toward the body to warm the brandy. She is quite beautiful.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What else do you have on this man Thorwald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough to scare me that you wouldn't get here in time, and we'd lose him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Soberly) You think he's getting out of here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything he owns is laid out on the bedroom, ready for packing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Doyle reacts to her appreciatively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT She continues rotating the brandy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes forward hands one snifter to Jeff. She offers the second to Doyle. (NOTE: In the following set of scenes, whenever anyone holds a brandy snifter, it is being rotated- regardless of their attitudes.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle sort of smiles, and takes the snifter awkwardly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle bows his head slightly, but his eyes remain on her in a fixed stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa smiles in return.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns around, and goes right back into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just warming some brandy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Doyle? -- I presume.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom, this is Miss Lisa Fremont.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We think Thorwald's guilty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle stares after her, ignoring her remark, still not recovered from the fist sight of her attractiveness. Then quickly, his eyes move down and to the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP The open overnight case with its displayed lingerie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly Doyle's eyes travel back to Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Quickly guessing what's on Doyle's mind
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Cautiously) Careful, Tom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle's eyes travel past Jeff to look out the window. He still holds the brandy snifter in one hand, and a cigarette in the other. Absentmindedly he still rotates the brandy. The SOUND of the phone ringing is heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He listens, and then looks up to Doyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle crosses and stands behind Jeff, as Jeff hands him the Phone. He juggles the cigarette, the brandy snifter and the phone all at once. This is all done deadpan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands the receiver back to Jeff, who hangs up. Lisa comes back in with her own brandy snifter, rotating it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle looks suddenly interested. He asks tersely:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns his head to Lisa, who answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His head snaps back to Jeff, who answers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His head moves back to Lisa as she answers with a touch of pride in her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Doyle can comment, Jeff asks impatiently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle smiles at Jeff, and then strolls over to the table where he puts out his cigarette and puts down the brandy snifter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle goes to the window and looks out, as they watch him, expectantly. He speaks without looking at them. His voice is flat and to the point.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hallo?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a minute, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doyle speaking. (He listens) Uh-huh. -- Yeah. Mummmm -- Mmm. Hmm -- Okay. Thank you, and goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The coffee will be ready soon. (Urgent) Jeff, aren't you going to tell him about the jewelry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jewelry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has his wife's jewelry hidden in among his clothes over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure it belongs to his wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was in her favorite handbag -- And, Mr. Doyle, that can lead to only one conclusion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Namely?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That wasn't Mrs. Thorwald who left with him yesterday morning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You figured that out, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just that women don't leave jewelry behind when they go on a trip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Tom -- you don't really need any of this information, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a matter of fact, I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lars Thorwald is no more a murderer than I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff and Lisa stare at him in astonishment. Then Jeff recovers, and answers with some anger:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You mean you can explain everything that went on over there -- and is still going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP He spins around, and his face has lost all its friendliness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts to place the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And neither can you. (Points out window) That's a secret and private world you're looking into out there. People do a lot at things in private that they couldn't explain in public.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa and Jeff. She replies with some sarcasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. JEFF'S APARTMENT - NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle breaks in, takes a step forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Like disposing of their wives?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Get that idea out of your mind. It will only lead you in the wrong direction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Tom -- the saw, the knives --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you ever own a saw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Well, in the garage, back home, we -- DOYLE (Interrupts) And how many people did you cut up with the couple of with it? Or hundred knives you've probably owned in your lifetime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff, reasoning:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa cuts in spiritedly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm not a killer!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Your logic is backward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't ignore the wife disappearing! And the trunk -- and the jewelry -- !
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle starts to pace up and down, throwing out a hand in careful explanation.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I checked the railroad station. He bought a ticket. He put her on the train ten minutes later. Destination: Merritsville. Witnesses. This deep. (He holds his hand a few feet off the floor)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff and Lisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: INT. JEFF'S APARTMENT - NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle comes up to the CAMERA, looking at Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It might have been a woman -- but it couldn't have been Mrs. Thorwald. That jewelry --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Miss Fremont. That feminine intuition sells magazines -- but in real life, it's still a fairy tale. I don't know how many wasted years I've spent running down leads based on women's intuitions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff is resentful of Doyle's comments to Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I take it you didn't find the trunk -- And this is just an old speech you once gave at the Policeman's Ball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle has turned away into the center of the room. He swings around.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I found the trunk -- a half hour after I left here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa speaks again with continuing sarcasm:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, it's normal for a man to tie his trunk up with a heavy rope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) When the lock is broken -- yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was in the trunk? A surly note to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle comes toward the CAMERA again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle gives her a scathing look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Carefully) Mrs. -- Thorwald's -- clothes. -- Clean -- carefully packed -- not too stylish -- but presentable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Didn't you take it to the crime lab?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent it on its merry and legal way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff challenges Doyle:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why -- when a woman only goes on a simple trip, does she take everything she owns?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Doyle, with a studied, gracious gesture, to Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let the female psychology department handle that one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa answers, but very coldly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I would say that is looked as if she wasn't coming back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) That's what they call a family problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Persisting) If his wife wasn't coming back -- why didn't he tell his landlord? -- I'll answer it for you -- because he had something to hide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Doyle hesitates a moment, and lets his eyes wander, to:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP The overnight case, with Lisa's lingerie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP His eyes going back to Jeff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Blandly) Do -- uh -- you tell your landlord everything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff replies, pointedly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa looks down at Jeff, not comprehending.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I told you to be careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle points to one of the photographs on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle has a complete change of manner. He relaxes and smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If I'd been careful piloting that reconnaissance plane, you wouldn't have taken the kind of pictures that got you a medal, a big job, fame, money -- JEFF (Expressionless) All the things I hate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now -- what do you say we sit down to a quiet, friendly drink or two -- forget all about this, and tell lies about the old days in the war? Hmmm? He looks from one to the other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Neither Jeff or Lisa display even the slightest friendliness. Their faces are cold and set. Then Lisa speaks, icily:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're through with the case?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle is relaxed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There isn't any "case" to be through with, Miss Fremont. Now let's get down to that friendly drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff and Lisa remain unmoved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP A little self-conscious, Doyle checks his watch, and says with a pleasant laugh:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waits. No response comes across. His face sobers a little, he reaches for his unfinished drink of brandy. He tries to toss it off like a straight shot of liquor. Part of it shoots out of the brandy snifter, down each side of his face, and into his suit. He sputters a little, and puts the glass down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you're right. I guess I'd better get home and get some sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff and Lisa deadpan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Doyle is wiping his coat lapels with a handkerchief. He looks at them pleasantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts away toward the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not much of a snifter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you need any more help, Jeff -- consult the yellow pages of your telephone directory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa, still burning:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hate funny exit lines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who was the trunk addressed to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Doyle picks up his hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts up the steps to the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Anna Thorwald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff points out a challenging finger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's wait and see who picks it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Doyle poises on the step. He snaps his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts on his hat, smiles, and says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He quietly closes the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh -- that phone call! (To Jeff) I gave them your number -- hope you don't mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) That depends on who "they" were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Pleasantly) The police Department at Merritsville. They called to report. The trunk was just picked up -- by Mrs. Anna Thorwald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't stay up too late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa and Jeff. Jeff turns his chair around, and looks out to the neighborhood. Lisa stands glumly behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The song-writer's party is now in full swing, and fairly crowded. It is a happy, gay affair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP None of the gaiety is reflected in Lisa and Jeff. Some new music is heard coming across the courtyard and Jeff turns toward it with some irritation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Torso's apartment has the door closed, and all that we can see of her, as she is lying on the divan, is her legs swinging in arcs as she exercise to record music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Lisa is not looking in the same direction as Jeff. All during this, she has been staring out at Thorwald's apartment. Now her eyes are looking at the apartment underneath. She murmurs to Jeff:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff turns his eyes in the same direction as hers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT A light has gone on in Miss Lonely Hearts' apartment. They look. Surprise of surprises, she has returned with a lover hooked. He is much younger then she, and a little more keyed up to the promise of an adventure still fresh to him. Her actions are coy, and over-feminine. She slips away from his hasty embraces and exploratory kisses with the proper flush of confusion and nervous giggle that seems to say, "It's quite a surprise you find me so desirable, but me mustn't do anything improper, you know. After all, we're practically strangers -- and what would you think of me?" She pours a drink for each of them with gestures over-genteel. As she sips her drink and look at him over the rim of the glass, he tosses his off with nervous dispatch. He moves toward her, this time more cautiously. An embrace, a long kiss. She puts her drink down on the edge of the chair. It spills over onto the rug. He begins kissing her cheek, her ear, her neck. Suddenly and fiercely she pushes him away. Slaps him across the face. He moves back with shock as she loudly and emphatically orders him out, out, out. He flushes with anger and embarrassment, and his mouth twists into unpleasant shapes as he slaps degrading words back at her, telling her what she is. She screams at him to get out. He leaves, slamming the door behind him. She goes back dumbly to the spilled liquor, makes a futile effort to clean it up, and the collapses onto the rug sobbing hard enough to shake her whole body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa turns away from Jeff's chair to get a cigarette from the table. She lights it, as Jeff turns his chair back to the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He indicates the outside neighborhood with a movement of his head. She doesn't answer, but studies the photographs on the wall of his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff starts to smile at the realization.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff smile is broad, and he starts to chuckle. She relaxes and joins him. She sits on his lap, her arms around his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets up, goes to the blinds, and proceeds to lower them one by on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles. She goes to the table, picks up he overnight case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes to the kitchen entrance, pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shrugs, goes into the kitchen, the CAMERA PANNING her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As much as I hate to give Thomas J. Doyle too much credit, he might have gotten a hold of something when he said this was pretty private stuff going on out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you suppose it's ethical to watch a man with binoculars, and a long- focus lens -- until you can see the freckles on the back of his neck, and almost read his mail -- do you suppose it's ethical even if you prove he didn't commit a crime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not much on rear window ethics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, they have the same chance. They can look at me like a bug under glass, if they want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Turns to him) Jeff -- if anybody walked in here, I don't think they'd believe what they see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and me with long faces -- plunged into despair -- because we find out that a man didn't kill his wife. We're two of the most frightening ghouls I've ever known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think we could be a little bit happy that the poor woman is alive and well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever happened to that old saying "Love Thy Neighbor."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I'll start reviving it tomorrow, with say -- Miss Torso for a start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (As she get up) Not if I have to move into an apartment across the courtyard and do the dance of the seven veils once an hour. (As she lowers the blinds) Show's over for tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Preview -- of the coming attractions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did Mr. Doyle think I stole this case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Mock seriousness) No, Lisa -- I don't think he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff is sitting on the wheelchair near the bar, a drink in his hand. He starts to take a sip from the glass, when Lisa comes out of the kitchen. She is an ethereal beauty, in sheer peach nightgown, covered by a gossamer matching kimono. She turns gracefully in front of Jeff. He lowers his drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff puts his drink on the bar. He tries to decide how to answer her question. He can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa holds out the folds of her kimono.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa turns playfully toward the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blood-curdling scream from the courtyard outside suddenly cuts through the night. Startled, both Jeff and Lisa move quickly for the window -- Lisa lifting the blinds up. The long scream subsides into near-hysterical sobbing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Softly) What do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll rephrase the question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you like it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Studying it) Well, -- if there was one less thread this way -- (motions horizontally)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and two less that way -- (Motions vertically)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might give up bachelorhood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LONG SHOT We get a high comprehensive view of all the apartments. Light are going on in some windows, shades are lifted on others, people are beginning to lean out looking for the source of the cream and sobbing. The song-writer's party comes to a sudden halt, as his guest crowd to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa and Jeff at the window, looking out, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The landlord, beneath the newlyweds, looks out. Tilting his head up toward the center of the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple comes out on the high balcony to the right. Look down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The newlywed's blinds come up, and for the first time we see both of them at the window, the girl looking over the boy's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some members of the song-writer's party move out to the patio- balcony, to get a better look down in the yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bird woman comes to the window. Her white face looks forward toward the center of the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Torso, pulling a around her, comes out onto her porch, and looks to her left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hearing aid comes quickly into her backyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The couple who own the dog are standing on their fire escape. They are both looking down, but while the husband is quiet, the wife is holding her hands to the side of her head, sobbing loudly. We have heard her sobbing since the moment of the scream which she uttered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lying near the sidewalk in the backyard below the couple's fire escape, is the silent body of the little dog they own. Miss Lonely Hearts comes running out of the basement door. She goes directly to the dog, picks it up in her arms. Then she slowly turns and looks up at the sobbing woman above her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Her voice clear) It's dead! It's been strangled and the neck is broken!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Instead of increasing her sobbing, this news quiets, momentarily, the woman who owned the dog. Her hands go down to the railing of the fire escape, gripping it fiercely. She lifts her face to the neighborhood, her lips set and her eyes burning. Her chest moves convulsively from the crying.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Which one of you did it? (Loud) Which one of you killed my dog? (No one answers; her voice is acid) You don't know the meaning of the word "neighbor". Neighbors like each other -- speak to each other -- care if anybody lives or dies. But none of you do! You don't talk, you don't help, you -- you don't --- (Fighting tears) Even see. But I couldn't imagine any Even of you being so low that you'd kill a little helpless, friendly dog! The only thing in this whole neighborhood who liked anybody!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The guests at the song-writer's party begin to move silently back to the studio apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people move off their balcony into the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman almost screams at the people now, as she looks up at the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She breaks out sobbing anew, and returns to her apartment and out of sight, the crying growing fainter with her retreat. The husband leans over the fire-escape, and motions Miss Lonely Hearts to place the dog in the basket, which is already lowered.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you kill him because he liked you? Just because he liked you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Miss Lonely Hearts puts the dog in the basket, and watches as the husband draws it slowly up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bathing beauties go inside their apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The newlyweds draw their shades again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The landlord moves away from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dog moves closer to the fire escape, slowly, the husband pulling the rope in hand over hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Torso goes back to her apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hearing Aid turns down the volume of her hearing aid and goes back to her apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dog reaches the fire escape, and the husband tenderly takes it out of the basket. He turns to carry it's into the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff and Lisa are at the window. He is holding on of hands. Jeff speaks without looking up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For a minute, Doyle almost had me convinced I was wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you're not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the whole courtyard, only one person didn't come to the window. (He points)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. It is dark. The only light that can be seen in it is the glowing end of a cigar in the center of the room, back from the window -- as if Thorwald was sitting quietly on his sofa, smoking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa looks down at Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods solemnly and then turns back to the window, as both he and Lisa look again towards
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why would Thorwald want to kill a dog? (Almost a laugh) Because it knew too much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. Still dark, and only the unmoving glow of a cigar showing in the center of the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff, Stella and Lisa are grouped at the window, looking out. THE CAMERA is behind them. Jeff holds the long-focus lens to his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CAMERA SHOT We wee the upper part of the bedroom window, belonging to Thorwald. The lower part of the window is covered by a wall. In the bathroom, Thorwald is wiping the enameled wall with a damp cloth. He rubs at particular spots now and then. Over this we hear:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think this was worth waiting all day to see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he cleaning house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's washing down the bathroom walls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must have splattered a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT We now see their faces. Jeff lowers the camera with a long- focus lens. Neither he nor Lisa make any comment. Finally Stella blurts out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa turns away from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella also turns, interrupting her
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, why not? That's what we're all thinking. He killed her in there, and he has to wipe up the stains before he leaves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stella, your choice of words --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody's invented polite words yet for killing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP Jeff, who is still staring out the window, has a look of sudden discovery on his face. He calls quickly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns halfway around, and points. We see Lisa moving behind him toward the shelf. He adds:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back to the window, holding out his right hand to the side, waiting for the box and viewer. The CAMERA PULLS BACK a little as Lisa comes up, and places the box and viewer in his hand. He opens the box, which contains color slides, and holds one or two of the slides up to the light. Lisa looks down at him curiously and Stella comes forward from the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Puts the other slides to one side and puts the selected one onto the viewer, with sounds of satisfaction. As he lifts the viewer to his eyes Lisa asks impatiently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He squints out through the viewer, then looks away a moment without it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks back through the viewer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the viewer from his eye, hands it to Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa -- Lisa -- on the shelf over there -- get me the small yellow box --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that little viewer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Half to himself as he searches slides) These aren't more than two weeks old -- I hope I didn't take all leg art. (Discovers the right slide) I think this is the one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- what are you looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something -- that if I'm right -- might solve a murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Thorwald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-uh. The dog. I think I know now why Thorwald killed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You take a look and tell me what you see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP Lisa raises the viewer to her eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DUSK - CLOSEUP Through the viewer we see the identical view out of the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The viewer moves away, and we are left with the identical scene, but not quite so still, a slight breeze stirring the foliage.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Over) Now take it away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff looks up to a puzzled Lisa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all lean forward to look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's just a picture of the backyard, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. But there's one important change. The flowers in Thorwald's pet flower bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean the one the dog was sniffing around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Stella) And digging in. (Points out window) Look at that flower bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT The flower bed. The flowers have a slight dip in the center. Jeff speaks off:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's a dip at this end. And since when do flowers grow shorter in two weeks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's something buried there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT All three ease back in awe. Lisa, still looking out, says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Stella begins to chuckle. They look around at her. Her face sobers as she answers their unasked question:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff and Lisa slowly turn their heads to look out at the garden.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Breathing it) Mrs. Thorwald!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't spent much time in cemeteries, have you? (they don't answer) Mr. Thorwald could hardly put his wife into a plot of ground scarcely one foot square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - SEMI-LONG SHOT The garden again with its small indentation of flowers over this we hear the ghoulish voice of Stella:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Unless, he puts in standing on end -- which would be very original and not require the use of either a knife or a saw. My guess is she's scattered all over town. A leg in the East River -- an arm -- LISA (Cuts in) Stella, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DUSK - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff looks at Stella.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halfway through Lisa's speech, Jeff begins speaking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Something's in there. Those flowers have been taken up, and put back again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Has a hard time saying it) It could be -- the knife, and the saw.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Quickly) Call Lieutenant Doyle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- let's wait. Let's wait until it gets dark. I'll go over and dig it up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Stella) I'm not going to call Doyle until I show him the body of Mrs. Thorwald -- (To Lisa) And you're not going to dig up anything, an get your neck broken too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to allow Lisa to sit on the divan, and Jeff turn his chair toward her. Stella still look out the window, thinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella's quiet voice brings him to a halt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff whips back to the window; Lisa turns to look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What we've got to do is find some way to get in there, and --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's starting to pack.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald, in the bedroom, methodically folding a suit into a suitcase. Another suitcase, unopened, is visible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff is staring out, gripping his chair tightly. There is a touch of desperation on his face. He looks down at the flowers, briefly, then swings around abruptly. He wheels away from the camera to the wall cabinet. We see him take a piece of notepaper, a pencil and an envelope. He puts a name on the envelope, and then proceeds to write something on the sheet of paper. Stella and Lisa edge up behind him, and look down at what he is writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP THE CAMERA RUSHES DOWN over Jeff's shoulder, just in time to catch the last word as he finishes writing the message. The envelope is addressed to "LARS THORWALD." The massage reads, simply, "WHAT HAVE YOU DONE WITH HER?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff at the window, looking through the long-focus lens. We get a glimpse of Stella behind him. He is watching:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT The alleyway and street. Just regular traffic. Suddenly Lisa comes into the picture from the left. She is carrying a white envelope. She stops, waves her hands at Jeff, smiles, and then hurries on. The lens slowly pans to the right and stops on Miss Torso's apartment. She is standing on a small stepladder, nailing curtains above her window. Her legs are bare, though she wears high-heel shoes. We do not see more than half-way up her thighs. The lens takes this in for the briefest split-second of hesitancy then moves on to await the arrival of Lisa along Thorwald's corridor. She does not appear yet. The lens moves back to get another glimpse of Miss Torso, who is now descending the ladder. She is wearing a leotard. Over this, we hear Stella's voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lens quickly swings back to Thorwald's corridor. Lisa is seen turning the corner, and approaching Thorwald's door on tiptoe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going back for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the long-focus lens to get a more comprehensive view of Thorwald's apartment and corridor outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa approaches the door of Thorwald's apartment. The salesman comes into the living room. He finds a package of cigarettes, extracts one, and lights it. Lisa kneels down, and carefully slides the letter under the door. At this moment, Thorwald extinguishes the match, tosses it into an ashtray, and turns toward the door. He freezes as he sees the letter on the floor. This momentary hesitation allows Lisa to straighten up, turn, and walk carefully but swiftly, away. Thorwald moves rapidly toward the door. He bends down, scoops up the letter, and examines it briefly. Lisa is just turning out of sight at the end of the corridor, as Thorwald throws open the door. He looks and sees no one. He takes a few questioning steps down the corridor, then stops to examine the letter again. Slowly he turns and makes his way back to the apartment, tearing open the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lifts the long-focus lens to his eyes again. His expression is tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Thorwald stops in front of his door to read the note. There is some curiosity on his face. As he reads, all movement and emotion drain from his body. He stands there, frozen. Jeff's voice is heard over:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Thorwald turns and dashes down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You did it, Thorwald! You did it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff whips the long-focus lens from his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT As Thorwald dashes down the corridor, we hear Jeff's voice. He cries out instinctively, but almost to himself:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa! Look out! He's coming!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Both Stella and Jeff frantic.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Accusingly) You shouldn't have let her do that! If he ever -- JEFF (Interrupting) Look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa suddenly appears at the ground floor door below Thorwald's. She hides, pressing back against the wall tensely. In the corridor above, Thorwald returns, frustrated. He comes out onto the fire escape directly above Lisa. She is aware of him, and immediately retreats into the doorway. She disappears down the lower corridor, as Thorwald searches his fire escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP There is a sigh of relief from both of them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank heaven that's over!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a feeling we've just begun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald is now passing through the living room into the bedroom. He picks up a shirt and puts it on. He then returns to packing his suitcases, moving unhurriedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff rubs his chin thoughtfully. Stella is scanning the neighborhood. We hear a radio, or a television show, off; and there is distant, rhythmic music coming from the cafe on Thorwald's street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella's brow knits a little as she sees something. She reaches for the long focus lens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lifts it to her eye.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No doubt of it. He's leaving. The question is -- when?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mind if I use the portable keyhole?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not as long as you tell me what you're looking at.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Miss Lonely Hearts' apartment. She has opened a small brown bottle, and taken out four red capsules which she places on the white table cloth of her little table. There is a candle burning in a holder, and other lamps also light the apartment. She is dressed in sedate street clothes. She sits at the table, and by the light of the candle proceeds to open a black-covered book, and read it. The print is fine. She bends over it a moment, looks up at the capsules, and returns to the book. She seems quite at peace. Stella and Jeff are heard over:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Lonely Hearts just laid out something that looks like sodium trieckonal capsules.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can tell that from here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I handled enough of those red pills to put everybody in New Jersey asleep for the winter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would four of them -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Breaks in) No -- but it makes the rest easy to take. And she's reading the Bible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (After a slight pause) Then I wouldn't worry too much. But let's keep an eye on her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Stella lowers the long-focus lens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door bursts open, and they both turn quickly toward the entrance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know? You might not be too bad a bargain for Lisa after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't say! I might just take that compliment as an insult.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa comes in, panting and flushed. She stands a second at the door, catching her breath, but smiling with the pleasure of sampling danger and escaping unharmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She comes down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wasn't that close?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Too close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was his reaction? I mean when he looked at the note?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT As Lisa comes up to the two of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa comes close to Jeff, speaks warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some of the pleasure goes out of her face. Stella notices it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It relieves the slight friction, as both Jeff and Lisa laugh. Lisa happens to look toward the window, and the laugh dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff and Stella turn toward the window. Jeff grabs the long- focus lens, lifts it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it wasn't the kind of expression that would get him a quick loan at the bank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- how did I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Real professional. Would have made a great layout for the Bazaar. The model pressed back against a brick wall, eyes wild, tense. Low cut bodice, in new suspicious black, with a --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Interrupts Jeff) You'd make a good door prize at a wake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- the handbag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Thorwald has the new alligator bag belonging to his wife, in his hand. He moves slowly across the bedroom, out of sight behind the door. He doesn't appear in the living room. In a moment he reappears, moving back to his packing. He puts the handbag into one of the suitcases -- the one which he has almost completed filling. He goes on with his packing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff puts down the long-focus lens, and turns around toward the room. The two women watch him expectantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella lifts her left hand, and looks fondly at her ring finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff looks at them aghast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella grows a little uneasy. Her eyes drift toward Thorwald's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa moves for the phone book on the stand near the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa hands him the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff looks for Thorwald's number in the directory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two women smile. Jeff picks up the phone and dials Chelsea 2-7099. The women watch him tensely. He holds the receiver away from his ear a little, and the buzzer is heard sounding on filter. Lisa looks toward Thorwald's apartment; then Stella; then Jeff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring was among the jewelry he has in the handbag. (Supporting his proposition) During that phone conversation he held up three rings -- one with a diamond -- one with a big stone of some kind -- and one plain gold band.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Excited) And the last thing she'd leave behind would be her wedding ring! (To Stella) Do you ever leave yours at home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only way anybody could get that off would be to chop my finger -- Let's go down and find out what's buried in the garden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? I always wanted to meet Mrs. Thorwald.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you two talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a shovel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's probably one in the basement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now wait a minute -- LISA Jeff, if you're squeamish, just don't look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now hold on. I'm not a bit squeamish about what might be under those flowers -- but I don't care to watch two women end up like that dog --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Lisa) You know, Miss Fremont -- he might just have something there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no point in taking unnecessary chances. (He points) Give me the phone book, Lisa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I can get Thorwald out of the apartment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We only need a few minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try to give you at least fifteen minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Finds the number) Chelsea 2-7099. (He looks up, reaches for the phone) We scared him once. Maybe we can scare him again. (Picks up receiver; pauses) I'm using that word "we" a little too freely, I guess. I don't take any of the chances.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall we vote him in, Stella?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unanimously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. He comes out of the bedroom toward the phone. He wears a light summer coat and tie, despite the heat. In the bedroom, everything is packed with the exception of one open suitcase. We see another suitcase, his sample case, and a couple of topcoats across the bed. He approaches the phone hesitantly, undecided whether or not to answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quickly Thorwald does pick it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a pause as Thorwald gropes for an answer. We can almost hear his breathing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up before Thorwald can reply. Thorwald looks at the receiver a moment, then he slowly hangs up. He stands at the phone thinking. He doesn't suspect he is being watched through the window. Then he makes up his mind and starts for the door. After he goes out he tests the door to make certain it is locked.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Off, half-aloud) Go ahead, Thorwald -- pick it up. You're curious. You wonder if it's your girl friend calling. The one you killed for. Pick it up, Thorwald!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Cautiously, on filter) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Did you get my note?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- did you get it, Thorwald?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give you a chance to find out. Meet me in the bar at the Brevoort -- and do it right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For a little business meeting -- to settle the estate of your late wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (After a pause) I don't know what you mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Firmly) Now stop wasting time, Thorwald, or I'll hang up and call the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Breathing heavily) I only have a hundred dollars or so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a start. I'm at the Brevoort now. I'll be looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Over) Let's go, Stella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff turns his wheelchair halfway around as Lisa and Stella start quickly for the door, THE CAMERA PANNING THEM across the room. They pause at the sound of Jeff's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff calls after them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door slams off and we hear the footsteps of the women dying down the corridor as Jeff picks up the long-focus lens and takes a sight on the alleyway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: One of you watch this window. If I see him coming back, I'll signal with a flashbulb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Thorwald goes past the alley opening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff puts down the lens and wheels quickly to the wall cabinet. He finds a box of flash bulbs and a reflector. He puts them in his lap and returns to the window, putting the chair sideways. He leans out a little and looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Lisa is in the courtyard directly below Jeff's window. She has reached the stairway leading up and to the right. She looks, waves at Jeff as Stella comes up to her carrying a shovel. The two women hurry up the stairs toward the iron ladder they will use to climb the wall between Jeff's yard and that of Thorwald's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Jeff picks up the phone and quickly dials. The buzzer sounds on filter, then the phone is lifted. A woman's voice is heard and Jeff seems a little puzzled at the sound of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He squints out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is Doyle's house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is L. B. Jefferies, a friend of Tom's. Who am I talking with?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa has climbed over the wall and is helping Stella down into Thorwald's yard. The shovel is lying on the ground beside Lisa. Jeff's conversation continues over the action of the two women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff hangs up. Stella is now beginning to dig, carefully lifting the flowers off the center of the bed where they had dipped down. She places the flower plants on the sidewalk. Lisa stands facing Jeff's window and occasionally glances over her shoulder uneasily at Stella's work. At this moment, the sounds of musical instruments begin to be heard from the songwriter's apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is the baby sitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. When are they expected home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm hired 'til one. They went to dinner and maybe night-clubbing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if he calls in, tell him to get in touch with L. B. Jefferies right away. I might have quite a surprise for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does he have your number, Mr. Jefferies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He has it. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT A little annoyed at the interruption, Jeff turns to look at the studio apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT In the songwriter's apartment, several of his musician friends have gathered. One plays a guitar, another a clarinet, and so on. One by one they try out the theme of the songwriter's new melody, running through it in turn to become familiar with the notes. We, therefore, hear the melody played informally in different ways with different instruments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff shifts his eyes from the songwriter's apartment back to the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Stella is busy, expertly handling the shovel. Lisa has her back to the nurse, but looks apprehensively over her shoulder. She then looks up toward Jeff's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff gives her an encouraging little gesture with his hand. Then his eyes lift a little as he looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Lonely Hearts is sitting on the sofa, writing a note with a pad on her knee. Next to her, on the table, the pills are still in evidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff picks up the long-focus lens and trains it on the alleyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT The alleyway and street intersection, with normal night traffic, but no sign of Thorwald. THE CAMERA LENS PANS across and down to the hole being dug by Stella. We get an impression of Lisa's legs as we go by. The spade comes out of the hole and rests on the side. THE CAMERA LENS PANS up just in time to catch Stella turning up to Jeff. She throws out a helpless hand and shakes her head. "Nothing."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff lowers the lens and looks down at the two women with evident disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa glances up to Thorwald's apartment. She turns and gestures some instructions to Stella. Then she looks up at Jeff and gestures her intention to enter Thorwald's apartment. She turns and dashes toward Thorwald's fire escape as Stella makes a fruitless grab to restrain her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff, shocked and alarmed, calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks quickly toward the intersection and then right back to Lisa. Apparently no sight of Thorwald.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa -- no!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT While Lisa starts up the fire escape, we see Stella running toward the wall in the foreground to climb over it. Stella has abandoned the shovel and left the flowers and dirt strewn over the walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff, tense and wide-eyed, watches Lisa climb the fire escape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa climbs the fire escape to the second floor and the outside of Thorwald's apartment. She tries, unsuccessfully, to get through the window which opens into the kitchen from the fire escape. And then, with some difficulty, stretches and succeeds in getting in through the living room window, which is open. She goes directly to the bedroom and we see her bending over one of the suitcases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Jeff quickly picks up the long-focus lens and trains it on the salesman's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Lisa turns from the suitcase with the alligator handbag in her hand. There is an expression of triumph on her face. She opens it and her expression changes to dismay. She looks toward Jeff's apartment and, to communicate her dismay, she turns the handbag upside down. Nothing falls out. Empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP He lowers the long-focus lens and he is sweating with anxiety. He mutters, almost to himself:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes turn quickly to the alleyway and back again to Lisa.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. Come on! Get out of there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Lisa has dropped the bag on the bed and is now looking around the bedroom, looking for some place to start searching for the jewelry. She moves quickly to the dresser and begins opening the drawers to check them. She finds nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP As Jeff watches tensely, the door bursts open behind him and Stella hurries into the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff swings toward Stella. He reaches for the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he picks up the receiver, Stella pushes his hand down again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella looks out the window and her face registers shock. Jeff turns quickly to the window again, forgetting the phone for the moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ring Thorwald's phone the second you see him on the way back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to ring him now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give her another minute -- She's doing this for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss Lonely Hearts!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Miss Lonely Hearts is in the act of popping an envelope up against the table lamp on the table next to the sofa. From the same table, she takes a pill bottle and empties the contents into her left hand. Replacing the bottle, she picks up a glass of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear the sound of the receiver picked up, and Jeff starting to dial New York Police. At this moment, from the song- writer's apartment which has been quiet for a while, comes a new burst of melody. It is the melody which the song-writer has been composing during the past few days. Now it is rich, and full, and completed, as the musical group plays it. Miss Lonely Hearts lifts her head to listen, and slowly lowers the pills and glass of water into her lap, her whole purpose arrested by the beauty of what she hears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Off) Call the police!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff and Stella turn for a quick glimpse of the song-writer's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT A quick flash of the song-writer's apartment, and his musical group gathered around the piano.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe that music will delay her taking the pills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff and Stella look back to Thorwald's apartment. Jeff has the receiver to his ear, and the buzzer can be heard on filter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT At the bottom of the picture, Miss Lonely Hearts is still listening to the music, while in the apartment above Lisa appears into the living room from behind the doorway that leads to the bedroom. She looks across to the source of the music. She is as arrested by the melody as Miss Lonely Hearts. Then looking across to Jeff, she holds up her hands triumphantly to show him the jewelry she has discovered. At this point, Thorwald appears coming along the corridor of his apartment house! Lisa is completely unaware of his approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Stella is so shocked, she can only gasp for breath. Jeff, in near panic, shouts in anguish!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At this moment, the phone is picked up on filter, and a voice speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff opens his mouth to speak, but no words come out, as his attention is focused on:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa! Lisa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Precinct Six -- Sergeant Allgood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald at the door, unlocking it with his key. We see that Lisa has heard the sound, and looks toward the door, all but frozen with alarm. The Policeman on the phone repeats with studied irritation:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lisa dashes back into the bedroom just in time to avoid being seen by Thorwald as he opens the door and enters the apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Precinct Six -- Sergeant Allgood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff, urgently into phone, with a serious and rapid voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone is down on filter, and Jeff replaces his receiver.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A man is assaulting a woman at one two five west ninth street. Second floor rear. Make it fast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . B. Jefferies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Phone number?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Impatiently) Chelsea 2-5598.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald crosses the living room, and goes into the bedroom. Suddenly he looks onto the bed. He picks up the open alligator handbag. He turns, facing the window, looking down at the bag. He looks up in the direction of the living room. Then suddenly his whole frame stiffens, his head turns a little further around to his right. He is looking directly at Lisa who is out of our sight in the corner of the bedroom. He holds out the bag, and without moving, starts to question the unseen Lisa. He takes a little step forward, and his head begins to turn slightly to the left as Lisa begins to emerge into the living room, backing away slowly. By her gestures, and nervous laughter, she appears to be offering a lame excuse for being found in his apartment. He comes towards her, and enters the living room as well. Lisa edging toward the door, points to it as she apparently argues with him as to the way she came in. He points to the window. She makes one more step toward the door, but Thorwald reaches out quickly and grabs her by the wrist. He twists it brutally, and flings her sideways into the sofa beneath the window. Her head snaps back against the head rest. With his right hand he throws the handbag across the room in anger, and with his left open-palmed he demands something from Lisa. Slowly her right hand comes up and opens. He takes the jewelry from her, looks at it for a surprised moment, puts it into his coat pocket. He reaches down with both hands, and by the wrists jerks her to her feet. He is talking viciously to her. We can hear Lisa calling out faintly: "Jeff! Jeff!" Thorwald suddenly looks out at the neighborhood. He realizes that somebody might be watching him. He drags her across the room, reaches up with one arm, and the lights go off. The faint light from the bedroom illuminates their struggle, but not clearly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP An angry Jeff is staring, and trying to penetrate the semi- darkness of Thorwald's room. Then he bends his head forward in despair, and after a brief moment speaks:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (With deep sincerity) Stella -- what can we do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Stella staring out, tense, frightened. Then her expression changes sharply as she looks slightly to the left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff looks up quickly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There they are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Two policemen move quickly and professionally up the corridor toward Thorwald's apartment. They stop at the door, listen a moment, and then push the buzzer insistently. Inside the apartment, lights go on, and Thorwald is in the center of the room looking toward the door. Lisa staggers away from him, trying to rearrange her clothes and her hair. She is as surprised at the interruption as Thorwald. He listens, looks back questioningly toward Lisa, then goes to the door. He passes into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff and Stella visibly relax. Jeff doesn't say anything, but a gesture of rubbing his eyes with the back of his hand gives an indication of how deep his tension was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT After a moment's hesitation, Thorwald goes to the door and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff quickly puts a hand out and takes up his long-focus lens. He looks through the finder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT Thorwald's head and shoulders fill the screen. For a moment Thorwald is genuinely frightened by the sight of the police. We see him listening to the policeman out of the picture. Thorwald turns slowly and we see him lose much of his fright and regain some control of his face. He completes his turn and is looking at the girl a little puzzled. He then swings back toward the police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP A quick flash of Jeff and Stella looking. Jeff still has the long-focus lens to his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald is displaying indignation and complaint to the police as he nods his head vigorously toward Lisa. At this the police start to advance into the apartment, going directly for Lisa. She flashes a quick look toward Jeff's window. She turns back as the first policeman reaches her. He starts to question her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Stella turns away and goes quickly to the table for the binoculars. Jeff still is using the long-focus lens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - BINOCULAR SHOT We see Lisa start to excuse her presence in the same manner she used with Thorwald previously, as if to say she came into the apartment by mistake. Thorwald, listening, comes quickly forward to contradict her, vigorously. He holds out the jewelry in his hand, and then picks up and shows the empty handbag. The policeman, impressed, looks back to Lisa for an explanation. She has none. Over this we hear Stella frantically asking:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first policeman indicates that Lisa is to come along with him. He pauses momentarily to tell the second policeman to take a statement from Thorwald about the attempted burglary. The second policeman reaches for the jewelry in Thorwald's hand, and takes it for examination. In the brief pause while the two policemen speak to each other, Lisa starts to wave her left hand behind her back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's she trying to do? Why doesn't she turn him in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smart girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Smart? She'll be arrested!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll get her out of there, won't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff looking through his camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CAMERA SHOT We get a closer view of the waving hand. She stops waving and holds her fingers spread out. With her other hand she points to the wedding ring on her left hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Thorwald's ring!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S UPWARD AND ACROSS until it brings Thorwald's profile into the picture. He is looking down directly at Lisa's hands. His head slowly turns, and he looks right up -- directly into the lens. Suddenly he becomes aware that Lisa is signaling to someone who is watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff and Stella. He drops the camera into his lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella hurries from the window, turning off lights, as Jeff backs his chair into the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stella! The lights! He'd seen us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT As Thorwald's attention is drawn back to the second policeman to answer further questions, the first policeman takes Lisa by the arm and leads her out of the apartment. He goes down the corridor pushing the curious people away from the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The last light out, Stella stops to catch her breath, and turns to Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff points to a drawer in the wall cabinets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella moves to get it.
direction.name: direction
