direction.raw_text: She finds a billfold, hands it to Jeff. He takes it, extracts some bills and begins counting them. As he counts, Stella comments:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up sharply at her, and then without comment goes back to counting the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella, following his pointing finger, gets a piggy bank down from a shelf on the sideboard. He takes it, cracks it on the knee of his cast. It splits open, and some money comes out. Mostly bills, a few silver halves. What he doesn't get, Stella picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff does, as Stella gets her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella goes up to the door. The phone RINGS. Jeff grabs it, picks it up. Stella pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stella goes quickly out the door. He returns to the phone call, glancing at the same time toward the courtyard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you took your first snapshot -- did you ever think it would bring you to this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Urgently) Stella -- how long do you think he'll stay there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Squinting out window) Unless he's dumber than I think, he won't wait 'til his lease is up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My billfold! In the right hand drawer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you need money for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To bail Lisa out of jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know -- you could just leave her there until after next Tuesday -- so you could sneak away safely -- as planned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (With obvious disappointment) One hundred and twenty-seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much do you think you'll need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First offense burglary -- (He shrugs)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: probably two-fifty. (Gets an idea, points) The piggy bank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thirty-three here. Totals one-ninety. Not enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got twenty or so in my purse. Give me what you've got.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about the rest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When those cops get a look at Miss Fremont -- they'll even contribute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To phone) Just a minute. (To Stella) I'll tell you who it is when you get back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP JEFF Jefferies.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Filter) This is Doyle, Jeff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Urgently) Tom, I've got something real big for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Wearily) Look Jeff, don't louse up my night with another man killer stuffing a grisly trunk that turns out to be -- JEFF (Interrupting harshly) Listen to me! Lisa's been arrested.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Slightest pause) Your Lisa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My Lisa. She went into Thorwald's apartment, and he came back. The only way I could get her out was to call the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Angry) I told you that -- JEFF (Interrupting) I know what you told me! She went in to get evidence, and she came out with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like Mrs. Thorwald's wedding ring. If that woman were still alive, she'd be wearing it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Grudgingly) A possibility.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Talking fast) A fact! Last night he killed a dog for pawing in his garden. Why? Because he had something buried in there. Something a dog could scent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like an old hambone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Fast) I don't know what pet name Thorwald had for his wife. And that night he went out half a dozen times with the metal suitcase. He wasn't taking his possessions, because they're up in his apartment now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think perhaps it was "old hambone?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In sections! And one other thing, doubting Tom -- it just occurred to me that all the calls Thorwald made were long distance! If he called his wife the day she left -- after she arrived in Merritsville -- why did she need to send him a postcard saying she'd arrived?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (After pause; a detective) Where'd they take Lisa?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Precinct Six. I sent a friend over with bail money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you won't need it. I'll run it down, Jeff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - LONG SHOT We see Thorwald leave his apartment and proceed down the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up, and just as he does, Jeff looks toward Thorwald's apartment. He rolls forward to the window. He seems a little puzzled by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just don't dally. Thorwald knows he's being watched. He won't hang around long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that ring checks out, we'll give him an escort. So long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Thorwald's apartment. Completely dark. No movement, or glow of a cigar. The corridor outside lighted, but empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Jeff scratches the side of his chin, studies Thorwald's apartment as if he might see some small clue as to where the salesman is. He looks toward the intersection to his left. Apparently he sees nothing. He turns to look down into the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Miss Lonely Hearts is standing in the yard outside her apartment, looking up to the porch of Miss Torso. The ballet dancer is in high heels and a fresh summer dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She indicates the song-writer's apartment. Miss Lonely Hearts turns, looks up at the studio apartment a moment, then looks up at Miss Torso.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Faintly heard) Have you heard that song he's been writing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Nods yes) I'm glad I was here when he played it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSE SHOT He sits quietly a moment, thinking. Suddenly he jumps a little as the phone rings. He reaches for it, picks up the receiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly he looks up toward Thorwald's apartment. Then, back to the receiver. On filter, a receiver can be heard carefully being replaced. Jeff slowly lowers the phone into the cradle. He looks once more toward Thorwald's apartment. Then he turns his chair around quickly and looks toward the door to his apartment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (Still looks out window) Hello. (No answer) Hello, Doyle? Tom? Tom, I think Thorwald's left. I don't see anything of -- (He looks at receiver, then:) Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The door. Quiet in the apartment, and in the corridor. Light showing beneath the door from the hall light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSE SHOT Jeff watching, waiting, nervous at first. He reaches for the phone, changes his mind. He looks around for some kind of a weapon, finds none to suit him. He hears the slightest squeak of a floorboard, and looks quickly toward the door again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The door. Another squeak of a floorboard, so light and quickly passing that at any other time it would have no significance, even if it could be heard. Then the light beneath the door disappears. Black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSE SHOT Jeff squints at the door, blinks, squints again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The door. No doubt about it, black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT He looks again for a weapon, and almost by instinct he snatches up his flash holder and the small packet of bulbs he had taken out to signal Lisa earlier. He tries to move his wheelchair farther into the shadows. His eyes are glued to the door of his apartment, and his senses are sharp as a hunting dog's. He scarcely breathes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Only the slightest sound is heard as the doorknob turns. The door slowly and carefully swings open, but the corridor is too dark to tell at first who is entering. The door closes just as quietly. From the shadowed recess comes a heavy voice. A threatening voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff doesn't answer. Thorwald steps to the top of the stairs, and is now somewhat visible. He looks tall and huge and explosive.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want from me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your friend -- the girl -- could have turned me in. Why didn't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff doesn't answer. His eyes watch Thorwald. He licks his lip with nervous tension and grips the flash holder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald comes down the two steps, pauses at the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jeff doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves forward a couple of steps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it you want? A lot of money? I don't have any money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say something!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Sudden loud anger) Say something! Tell me what you want!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff still doesn't speak. He grips the flash holder a little more tightly, lifts it just the fraction of an inch as if he is prepared to use it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Thorwald has advanced to the middle of the room, his eyes on Jeff and his hands clenching with the effort to control his anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He advances a step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thorwald starts to move threateningly for Jeff.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can you get me that ring back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Quietly) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Loud) Tell her to bring it back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't. The police have it by now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then if the police get me -- you won't be around to laugh!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP From a three-quarter angle toward Thorwald. Jeff lifts the flash holder to face level and closes his eyes. He explodes the flash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Thorwald's face fills the screen registering shock, confusion. He throws up his hands for protection and recoils, making an involuntary sound of surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A vision of Jeff and the apartment as seen by Thorwald. It is distorted and out of focus, filled with large twisting balls of bright yellow color.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Thorwald blinking, trying to regain his sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Jeff ejects the used bulb and quickly inserts another. He works furiously, sweating. He gets the bulb in the flash holder just in time to meet Thorwald coming at him. Jeff closes his eyes and another bulb explodes in Thorwald's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Thorwald's face, full screen again, as he recoils from the flash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The apartment as seen by Thorwald again. Big, twisting balls of blinding yellow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald stumbles back against the side table, knocking objects off onto the floor, struggling for balance and sight. Jeff works rapidly to put a fresh bulb in the holder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Thorwald regains his equilibrium and some of his sight. Orienting himself, he starts for Jeff again. This time, when the flash holder goes off, we see it from Jeff's angle. Thorwald is lighted almost white, shockingly outlining every detail of his face, clothes, hands. His rage and frustration are fixed for a brief but terrifying moment. He stumbles backward again, trying to brush the light away from his face almost as if it were a solid enveloping substance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Jeff ejects a bulb, puts his last bulb into the flash holder. He tries to move the wheelchair a little further away from Thorwald. Then he raises the flash holder again. In b.g. we see: Doyle, Lisa, Stella and the detectives come to Thorwald's door, try it. Locked. One of the men steps forward with a flat steel jimmy and snaps the lock open. They move quickly into the darkened apartment. Doyle hits the lights inside the kitchen. The group goes into the living room. The lights go on. No sign of Thorwald. Doyle, Lisa and Stella instinctively turn and look toward Jeff's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT From Thorwald's apartment shooting at Jeff's window. A sudden bright flash is seen as the last flash bulb goes off. And it lights the scene of Jeff in the wheelchair and Thorwald diving through the air at him. Darkness rushes in, blacker than before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald has finally reached Jeff, knocking the flash equipment out of his hands and coming to grips with him. It is apparent that he is trying to pull Jeff out of the wheelchair. Jeff fights him off. The wheelchair crashes over, spilling Jeff to the floor. Thorwald is on top of him, lifting, dragging him to the window. Jeff grabs everything he can to keep himself away from the window, but Thorwald is far too powerful for him. He strains to raise Jeff to the windowsill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slowly, inexorably, he raises Jeff to the windowsill. Jeff frantically grabs for the upright window frame, wrapping his arms around it. Thorwald shoves the rest of his body over the windowsill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll give you a good look out the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Doyle, Lisa, Stella and the two detectives, crossing Thorwald's yard, see Jeff going out the window. Lisa is panicked.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff! Jeff!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM LONG SHOT From Doyle's viewpoint, Jeff hanging out the window and Thorwald hammering at his hands and arms with bare fists. Doyle pushes Lisa to one side and starts to scale the wall, preceded by the two detectives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald fights to dislodge Jeff's grip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSE SHOT Looking down on Jeff's face, showing his strain and the pain of Thorwald's attack. The brick floor of the patio seems a hundred feet below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald and Jeff struggling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Doyle pulling himself to the top of the wall. Lisa, Stella and the two men below, looking up. Lisa is white-faced and frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald smashes at Jeff's arms and hands. Jeff's grip begins to slip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Doyle reaches the top of the wall, looks up at Jeff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM LONG SHOT Jeff, as seen from Doyle's angle, hanging, somehow weathering Thorwald's insane attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Doyle reaches for his service revolver. He doesn't have it! He looks down, and calls one of the detectives back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Creel! Your Thirty-eight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Looking down at the two detectives from Doyle's point of view. Creel grabs for his gun expertly. The holster breaks away. It is in his hand and with a deft movement he tosses it upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Doyle catches it, turns up to Jeff's apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Thorwald still trying to loosen Jeff's grip. The salesman, in a complete, wild, sweating rage, is beyond all reason. His glasses hang from one ear, his coat is torn, his tie pulled to one side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM LONG SHOT Shooting over Doyle's shoulder as he steadies himself against the wall, lifting the service revolver up for a shot at Thorwald. His aim is careful, slow, painfully deliberate. Jeff seems about to fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT The two detectives ahead of Doyle are moving up below the window. Lisa stand looking up, her hands at the sides of her head, frozen with panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT Two detectives appear behind Thorwald and grab him. The startled Thorwald stops his attack on Jeff as he looks wildly around to find the source of his new attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - CLOSEUP Jeff, hanging from the window frame. He claws desperately for a hold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - COMPREHENSIVE SHOT People rush to their windows, looking out at the excitement. Some people on the ground floor come out into the yard. Doyle and the two detectives come into the patio beneath Jeff. Doyle directs them to improvise something to break Jeff's fall -- leaves, greenery, their coats, cushions from the patio furniture -- anything they can find. The four uniformed policemen rush into the backyard. Lisa and Stella come over the wall into the patio beneath Jeff. They look up at Jeff, encouraging him to hold on. A detective goes into Jeff's cellar door, trying to reach his apartment before Jeff loses his grip. The siffleuse and her husband are standing on the fire escape in plain, almost somber clothes. They watch expressionlessly. Beneath them the empty basket which once held their dog swings silently in the night air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MEDIUM SHOT Jeff, hanging from his windowsill. He loses his grip and plunges down into the patio below. Two detectives throw themselves beneath him. They are knocked to the ground as Jeff's fall tumbles both of them. After Jeff hits, he lies still, twisted over to one side. Doyle and Lisa rush over to Jeff. There is an audible
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of shock in the neighborhood as Jeff has fallen -- various oh's, ah's, and possibly a stifled scream or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSE SHOT Lisa kneels down, cradles Jeff's head in her lap. There are tears in her eyes. Her clothes are disheveled and her dress torn. Her hair is disarranged. But withal, her face is as beautiful as ever, with love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens his eyes. Winces with pain.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jeff -- Jeff darling!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To the detectives) Get an ambulance. (Down to Jeff) Don't move. Try to lie still.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lisa -- I -- I -- can't tell you how scared I was that you -- you might -- LISA (Affectionately) Shut up. I'm all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (To Doyle) Think you've got enough for a search warrant now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh sure. Sure. I can make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-LONG SHOT At that moment, a man appears leaning out of Jeff's window. He looks down to the patio.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant Doyle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Looking up) Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thorwald's ready to take us on a tour of the East River.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - SEMI-CLOSEUP Stella tugs at Doyle's arm and stands on tiptoe to whisper something into his ear. Doyle then looks up to the detective.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle turns quizzically at Stella.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did he say what was buried in the flower bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. It's over in his apartment. In a hat box. Wanna look?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no thanks -- I don't want any of part of her (She pauses, then does a surprised take back to Doyle) What did I say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY - PAN SHOT Beginning on Jeff's window thermometer, the CAMERA PANS FROM RIGHT TO LEFT around the neighborhood. In the songwriter's apartment we see the songwriter with a guest -- Miss Lonely Hearts. Both in dress and manner she seems quite happy and adjusted to life. The songwriter is placing the first recording of his new song on a record player for her to hear. It is a full symphonic arrangement which is heard over. CONTINUE TO PAN Thorwald's apartment is empty, stripped of its furnishings. Two painters are repainting the walls. The siffleuse and her husband are on their fire escape, training a new white dog to ride in their basket. Miss Torso is practicing her ballet again. She wears a white leotard. The sound of someone at the door interrupts her. She goes to the door, opens it an inch or two cautiously. When she sees who is outside, she throws open the door. An innocuous, unhandsome and somewhat shy army private enters with a barracks bag slung over one shoulder. She kisses him fondly after closing the door. He puts down the barracks bag, tosses his hat into a chair and, with the attitude of a man who belongs there, goes to the icebox to see what's to eat. The newlyweds are arguing. The CAMERA PANS past Jeff who is asleep in his wheelchair facing away from the window. CAMERA MOVES DOWN to the lower part of his body and we see that both his legs are now in casts. The CAMERA LIFTS SLIGHTLY to show Lisa sitting on the sofa nearby. She wears Levis and a plaid cotton shirt. She is reading a book on travel. She looks up briefly at Jeff. When she realizes he is asleep, she puts down the travel book and reaches for the latest copy of Harper's Bazaar. She settles down to study it as we
direction.name: direction
